sen.e: It started in 1878, when successive emperors and main imperial family members were equinoctially enshrined, twice a year in spring and autumn, according to the dates of their death.

sen.j: もともとこの日に最も近い戊の日は、社日として氏子が氏神たる神社に参詣し、春は五穀豊穣を祈り、秋は実りある収穫に感謝する習わしがあった。
sen.e: Tsuchinoe days (that fall closest to the Equinox Days) were originally known as shanichi, when shrine parishioner visited their ujigami shrine to pray for a good harvest in spring and to thank for a successful harvest in autumn.

Tsuchinoe days (that fall closest to the Equinox Days) were originally known as shanichi, when shrine parishioners visited their ujigami shrine to pray for a good harvest in spring and to thank for a successful harvest in autumn.

A Tsuchinoe day that falls closest to the vernal or autumnal equinox day was originally known as a shanichi day, and shrine parishioners visited shrines which enshrined their local deities to pray for a good harvest on the spring shanich day or to thank for a successful harvest on the autumn shanichi day.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 中国の歴史では祖廟を祀る日であった。
sen.e: The dates were to worship before a sobyo (mausoleum containing the remains of one's ancestors) in traditional China.
